Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. div.head: EGYPT'S CURSE.
div.p: The terrible theory of the Parisian scientist, Dr. Sornac, that tuberculosis is due to Egyptian mummies is thus discussed by Dr. Clifton Harby Levy in the pages of an American contemporary : —

If Dr. Sorgnac is right the world owe indying hatred to eternal Egypt. He is the first of modern scientists to announce that archaelogical research is responsible for the great White Plague. Perhaps he is right ; but the present state of scientific knowledge is not sufficient to say positively whether bacteria could live so many thousands of years or not. In fact, much that we do know point to the probability of the persistence of disease germs indefinitely. It is generally admitted by scientists that among bacteria are some species that are able to live without free oxygen, without light, and at a relatively high temperature, and this to an extent known among no other group of living beings.

It was the genius of Pasteur that proved that microbes, or microbe organisms, can live without any oxygen. He found that oxygen is taken from chemical compounds, constituting the food of the bacteria. It has also been proved that absence of air has a farther effect, it enables the microbes to retain for a long time their power of causing fermentation, of producing poison or of bringing about infection. Experiments by Fajans and Hueppe have shown that cholera cultures retain their viru- lance for weeks, and even months, under an-aerobic conditions after parallel cultures which have been freely exposed to air have since lost their potency. Bunzl-Federn has stated that the same thing is true of the very deadly pneumonia germ—and how much easier, than, it is to conceive of the long preservation of the tuberculosis germ.

The tremendous resistance power of bacilli has been proved over and over again by modern experiments. Simple freezing destroys some of the cells, but many withstand this shock. Several endure a still lower temperature than the vegetable forms, surviving for twenty hours at a temperature of 120 degrees. According to recent experiments by Pictet they survive and are able to multiply – being imbedded in frozen oxygen at 213 degrees.

Spores of some species are destroyed by hot water and steam only after six hours' exposure and by steam under pressure at 110 to 120 degrees after half an hour. In a dry condition, some withstand the action of high temperature to 170 degrees.

Cholera bacteria vary in their resistances and often exhibit differences of from a few hours to upward of eight months. Authrax, germs and other endospores have been found to be capable of development after remsining in a dry condition for the seemingly impossible period of ten years. This is absolutely demonstrated and gets rally accepted as true by scientific men. Now if it be true that one species of bacilli can live absolutely dried for ten years, and if it be true that no air is required to keep alive some germs, and if it be remembered that mummies were kept in hermetically sealed tombs or chambers for thousands of years, it is not impossible that in preserving the body of their dead the Egyptians at the same time kept alive—or in a state of suspended animation—the germs which caused the death of Pharaohs and their subjects during hundreds of years. It has been stated at various times that seeds of plants buried with mummies have grown when planted, and if this be true how much more probable is it that germs of tuberculosis, far more recent than any plant seed, may survive this long interval and when brought to light and air begin their peruicious activity again.

There is another presumption in favor of Dr. Sornac's theory, and that is the mummies themselves. The mods of embalming called mummifying was one which, while it was intended to preserve the flesh of the dead, undoubtedly could and did preserve any bacilli in the flesh. This is especially true of the Theban mode of mummifying, by which the flesh was so perfectly preserved that it even now yields to the touch and is not the hard, black flesh of Memphian mummies. If the balsams used were so efficacious for the preservation of human flesh it is more than possible that at the same time and unintentionally the genes of the diseases which killed these Egyptians may have been pre served in the same way. We must not forget that the science of bacteriology is a brand-new science, so new in fact, that we have not had the time as yet to test thoroughly the length of time that a dried bacterium may remain in a suspended state of animation. We do know that some of these when dried will survive a period of ten years and then return to activity. It is the preservation for the first year or two that is rather astonishing.

If a germ survive ten years there is no reason to believe that this germ remain in the same condition for ten centuries or twenty or thirty centuries under proper conditions. These conditions exist to a nicety in the tombs of Egypt. The bodies had been wrapped in moist linen first, and then, after continued wrapping, deposited in stone sarcophagi or coffins and placed in tombs which were hermetically sealed for ages. The temperature was an even, constant one, and it has been proved in connection with all organic matter that the dry soil of Egypt is a wonderful per- servative. Manuscripts for instance, that would have fallen to pieces when buried in any other soil have been perfectly preserved, and it is little wonder then, if the dried germs of disease have also kept in this manner, especially under the conditions of mummy making and burial. We know now to a certainty that the Egyptians were subject to much the same diseases as modern men of other countries, for the books or Egyptian physicians have been found and deciphered, and it is certain, from the symptoms mentioned and the prescriptions found, that none of our diseases are modern inventions, least of all the great white plague tuberculosis. In fact, some scholars have gone farther and carefully studied those historic plagues visited upon the Egyptians when the Israelites were in Egyptian bondage, as described in the Book if Exodus in the Bible, and they find at least he suggestion that some of our diseases appeared as these plagues. They claim that the last great and awful plague, when "the first born was stricken" even in Pharaoh's was consumption in its most terrible and rapid form. But whether this was the disease with which the Angel of Death struck down the chosen sons of Egypt or not we know that consumption prevailed in Egypt, and that during the 5,000 years that mummifying was practised in Egypt many millions of corpses of those who hid died of consumption most have been preserved, together with the fatal germ. It is not surprising that archaelogists have never thought of the dangers connected with their interesting pursuit for the wonders of be past and besides, in the early part of the nineteenth century, when Egyptian research was stimulated by Napoleon, no one dreamed of the science of bacteriology. For a full century now the museums of the world have coveted and fought for these old and when any have been secured they unrolled them without hesitation, scattering germs buried and preserved for thousands of years to sow the seeds of disease broadcast in Europe and America.

This is a varification of the Biblical "visiting the sins of the fathers upon the children" in a new and terrible sense. It is not upon the children, bat upon unborn generations, that this plague has fallen with all its terrors.

Scientists can easily suggest methods of slaying the germs lying in the mummy cases the very moment they are opened and before the germ laden wrappings are removed, and in this way scholars and lovers of ancient research may be protected from these unnecessary dangers. It is at least something well worthy of careful study and the exercise of proper precautions.

div.head: The Price of Loyalty.
div.p: The total subscription for the Accession Day Fêtes realised LE 396 !

div.head: Hashish Seizure.
div.p: The coast guards seized two sacks of hashish of the coast of Ramleh yesterday.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The Brindisi mail will be distributed at the G. P. O., Alexandria, at 9 p.m. to-morrow.

div.head: The Prison Departent.
div.p: The Mamours of the Egyptian Government prisons have received orders to henceforth wear military uniforms.

div.head: Coptic New Year.
div.p: To day is the Coptic New Year's Day and we wish all our Coptic readers a happy new year at the beginning of 1623.

div.head: New Police Station.
div.p: The Ministry of Finance has purchased a plot of land at Gabbary, 1432 metres in extent, for erecting a police station thereon.

div.head: Hydrophobia.
div.p: Instructions have been issued to the provincial governors and mudira regarding the measures to be taken for victims of hydrophobia.

div.head: New Coptic School.
div.p: To-day the Coptic Colony at Cairo will inaugurate its new industrial school at Berket el Rate. The Patriarch Cyril VIII. will preside et the inagural ceremony.

div.head: New Officers' Quarters.
div.p: A board of officers assembled at Abbassieh this morning in order to report on the site at Hareem Buildings, where it is proposed to build new officers' quarters.

div.head: Rotations.
div.p: The Nile being now in flood, the Ministry of Public Works is dismissing the rotation service staff, which includes Mr. Osborne Ashton, of Menoufieh province.

div.head: Imprisonment for Libel.
div.p: The Native Court of Appeal has sentenced Sheikh Mustapha El Shater, editor of "Al Mumtaz," to six months' imprisonment for libelling the telegraph employés at Tantah.

div.head: Stray Dogs.
div.p: To-morrow night at 11 o'clock all dogs found in the Shoubrah quarter will be poisoned by-order of the Governorate. Friends will accept this the only intimation.

div.head: Fatality on Mex Railway.
div.p: Yesterday afternoon a native man was run over by a locomotive on the Mex line and had his hands and feet cut off. He was taken to hospital where he succumbed to his injuries shortly afterwards.

div.head: Motor-Car Accident.
div.p: Yesterday at Zaher, Cairo, an old native, sixty-five years of age, by name Ahmed Khalaf. was run over by a motor-car and taken to hospital in a dying state. The driver of the automobile escaped.

div.head: French Consulate at Suez.
div.p: The French Foreign Office has promoted M. Altemer, French Vice-Consul at Suez, and at present on leave, to the rank of Consol. M.. Altemer will continue to be chargé d'affaires of the French Vice-Consolate at Suez.

div.head: San Stefano Casino.
div.p: We remind our readers of the Variety enter- tainment to-night, at 9.45 o'clock. To-morrow Mr. Longhi's "Live Dolls" give a performance. On the 20th inst. there will be a magnificent fête de nuit for the Italian National Festival.

div.head: Italian National Fete.
div.p: In celebration of this anniversary which falls on the 20th. inst, the Philodramatic Ermete Novelli Society have issued invitations for an open air entertainment at Kasr-El-Nil Terrace, under the auspices of the Italian Diplomatic Agent. The proceeds are in aid of the Umberto I. HoHospital.

div.head: Opera Square Incident.
div.p: Two of the Greeks who assaulted the British officers have been sentenced by their Consulate to twenty days' imprisonment. The Hellenic Agency has agreed with the Cairo Governorate to expel George Araghi and Alexander Koudzi until such time as they shall have amended their ways.

div.head: The Shoubra Crime.
div.p: The widow of the late Scopelitis is in Cairo, and intends taking civil action in the criminal proceedings against Paillard. The enquiry since Saturday has led to serious revelations, which will involve a farther arrest. The "Chambre de Conseil" of the Consoler Court meets to-day to adopt the necessary measures. Judge Vasquez has requested Paillard senior to absent himself from Court whilst the investigation is, proceeding.

div.head: Permanent Way Renewals.
div.p: During the past year, 90 ½ kilometres of track on the Egyptian Government Railways' system were renewed with rails. About 61 kilometers were relaid with steel bull-headed-rails, and 29 ½ with steel Vignola rails. The principal lines relaid were between Genefe and Sues Docks; part of the Zagazig to Manséurah line, and the Upper Egypt line between Bedresheinand Kafr-Ammar. At the end of 1905 the rail -ways had 64 kilometres of new rails on hand which could not be laid during the year.

div.head: Fire at Damanhour.
div.p: A serious fire broke out at Damanhour in the small hours of yesterday morning, at about 3 a.m. It started in a silor's shop in the Moudirieh street, and fanned by a strong wind, destroyed two other swellings. The Moudir was at once on the scene at the head of the fire brigade, and directed the work of combating the flames which was rendered very difficult owing to the dense smoke that blew into the firemen's faces. It was only after a hard fought fight that the fire was mastered, at four o'clock.

div.head: NILE TOURIST TRAFFIC.
INTERNATIONAL RIVALRY.
KEEN COMPETITION.
div.p: Three steamship companies under three different flags - American, German, and British —will seek to capture tourist traffic on the River Nile in the coming Winter season. The competition between the rival companies will be very keen, and it is not improbable that a rate war will ensue.

For many years Thomas Cook and Son had the monopoly of the Nile passenger traffic until 1896, when the Anglo-American Nile Navigation Company took a hand. The latter com-pany developed last Winter into the Hamburg- American Company, And the German flag will fly over the steamers Puritan and May-flower next season instead of the Stars and Stripes.

The "Express" Nile Navigation Company although an Egyptian Company, is to be run on up to-date American lines and has offices in New York. Two new steamers, the Virginian and the America, have been constructed for the company, and it is claimed that they will be the fastest steamers on the Nile. Their average speed upstream will be 12 knots an hour against the current, which runs at 2 1/9 or 3 knots an hour.

Nile cruises up to Assouan and back to Cairo occupy three weeks. The "Express" Nile company intends to make the trip in eight days at a cost of $100. One of their special features will be a daily steamer service between Luxor and Assouan, which will avoid the necessity of passengers making the disagreeable train journey across the desert.

Thomas Cook and Sons do not exhibit any alarm at the prospect of compétition, as they believe that the more advertising and publicity that is given to Egypt the greater will be the tide of tourist traffic.
"For years," said the manager of their America tourist department, "we had strong opposition from the Anglo-American Company, and our Nile business exceeded all previous bookings."

William Meyer, the New York passenger manager of the Hamburg-American Company, feels confident that their steamers would get their share of the traffic on the Nile. In, addition to the six steamers taken over from the Anglo-American Company, they had built two new vessels, the Germania and the Nubia. Two more vessels of similar type would be ready for the season of 1907-08. The German company has also entered into competition with Cooks on land by opening travel bureaus in New York, Chicago, and the principal cities in Europe, as well as erecting hotels in the Holy Land.

div.head: THE LATE PRINCE IBRAHIM.
div.p: The "Figaro" attributes the Bernay tragedy not to any imprudence on the part of the Prince, but to the lack of proper signals on this and other communal railways, which twisting through forests and fields are a positive danger. It concludes by drawing the attention of the Touring Club of France to this state of things.

Princess Sheveikiar, sister of the unfortunate Prince, and wife of Seifoullah Yusri Pasha, is suffering from heart attack, which was aggravated by the shock of the tragic death, she having been the first to attend to him, and remained by his bedside until his death.

div.head: THE KHEDIVIAL LAW SCHOOL.
div.p: Nine undergraduates of the Khédivial Law School who failed in this year's examination have been dismissed, and wrongly, to quote the "Moayad," which holds that they are entitled by the old regulations to a second trial as the new rule under which they are expelled came into force in February, five months only after they bad been admitted, and this, observes the journal, especially in view of the fact that the Ministry of Public Instruction had delayed the execution of a rule regarding school fees until the new term.
Our contemporary adds that the parents of tbese undergraduates intend taking action against the Ministry.

div.head: THE MAHROUSSA.
div.p: The Khedive's yacht, the Mahroussa, has been in the Guwan drydock, Glasgow, for the past few weeks being got ready for her trials, which were to commence to-day. Steam was got up in her boilers a week ego, and work on deck is now completed.

div.head: THE COMMERCIAL, INDUSTRIAL AND LAND COMPANY OF EGYPT LIMITED.
div.p: In reference to the letter which appeared in our issue of yesterday from a shareholder in the above Company, we understand that the circular announcing the purchase of the business of Messrs. Edgar Kirby and Company was prematurely sent out after the negotiations had been completed, but before the agreement had been signed.
At the last moment there was a disagreement about one of the clauses of the agreement, and consequently the negotiations fell through.

div.head: BRITISH CHAMBER OF COMMERCE.
div.p: The bulletin of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt for July has just made its appearance. It contains some practical hints for manufacturers, an interesting article on Egypt's floor trade, some extracts from the report for the past year's working of the Egyptian Government Railways, and a review of the imports during July, which we reproduce in another column.

div.head: THE ATBARA LINE REPAIRED.
DEATHS FROM SUNSTROKE.
div.p: Suakin 5th September. The forty days' struggle against the wash- outs came to an end yesterday, and all the damage has now been repaired, so that traffic on the railway, line is resumed once more. There are hopes that there will be no more wash-outs this year; at least not any of considerable importance. Mr. Urquhart, bridge contractor, Suakin- Atbara line, hat moved his masons and stone onttere from Thamiam to Port Sudan lies, where he has commenced excavations and stone quarrying for the bridges of Port Sudan railway line. Mr. Urquhart will complete his bridge contract from Suakin to Atbara in about a month's time. The question of the extra bridges to be added on to this line to combat next year's washouts is still under consideration. The Langdale lost, one of her first-class passengers by the name of Mr. Brown, who was bound for Mombassa from England, he having had a sunstroke in the morning of the 28th ult. Two native doctors attended him (there being no European doctor here at the time) and the same night he died. The funeral took place on the morning of the 29th ultc. the Rev. Blackledge reading the funeral service. Another sad death took place from sunstroke. The victim was Mr. Skoufos, chief clerk at the Khédivial Mail Agency, Suakin. He was quite a young man, a little over 20, wel edu- cated and of a good Greek family. He stood over six feet high, and was very much liked by Suakin society. He left for Port Sodan by the S.S. Dakahlieh in a critical condition to be treated by a European doctor there, but it was too late, and be passed away from this world on the 1st inst. The Rev. Blackledge, Army Chaplain, who is a passenger on board the S.S. Langdale, gave up his visiting Khartoum owing to the railway line being broken, and left by the S.S. Langdale for Mombasa (Uganda) on the 2nd inst. Kaimakam Longfield Bey, R.E, Chief Engineer and Assistant Director of the Sudan Railway, left by the S.S. Dakahlieh on the 29th ult. on leave of absence for England. Bimbashi Lord, RE, has moved from Gebeit to Atbara to act as Chief Engineer in place of Longfield Bey. Bimbashi Newcombs, R.E. Agent of the Sudan Government Railways, at Suakin, has cancelled his leave so that Mr. Hickley will not now relieve him, Mr. Hickley has gone to Gebeit to replace Bimbashi Lord as District Engineer, Suakin-Atbara line.

div.head: MOUDIR OF KENEH.
A RELAPSE.
div.p: Keneh, Tuesday, 10.30 a.m. I regret to state that Yessin Bey Moustapha, the Moudir of Keneh, after cancelling his leave and resuming his official duties at the Moudirieh for the spare of a single day, again felt the effects of his recent automobile accident and in consequence has had to apply to the Ministry for farther leave. He is leaving for Cairo to-night.

div.head: THE DENISHWAI AFFAIR.
div.p: We have received the following notice from T. Fisher Unwin: - A pamphlet by Mr. Wilfrid Blunt entitled "Atrocities of Justice under British Rule is Egypt" will be published by Mr. Unwin on September 10th. It has been called forth by the recent scandal of the trial and execution of the villagers of Denishwai. Its object is to trace the history of similar cases which have occurred in Egypt within the author's recollection, and in this way to show the essentially inequitable basis on which the criminal relations between Englishmen and native, especially between English officer. and Egyptian fellah, have been made to stand, as often as it has been thought advisable on political grounds to uphold the former and punish the latter.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: A native of the Labbane quarter of Alexandria was admitted yesterday into the Government Hospital suffering from bubonic plague.
A fatal case of plague has occured at Beni Suef Hospital, and also there has been a fresh case admitted to hospital there.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner 'Tabor" sailed from Malta yesterday afternoon, and is due here on Thurs- day evening or Friday morning next, the 14th inst., at daybreak, with passengers, mails, and a general cargo. The S.S. Kaffir Prince, with passengers and a general cargo, left Malta on Monday, the 10th inst, and is due to arrive at Alexandria on the 14th inst. The S.S. "Melbourne" from Antwerp with general cargo, left Algiers on Sunday, the 9th inst, and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Saturday, the 15th inst.

div.head: IMPORTS DURING JULY.
div.p: The net result of the operations through the Customs during the month of July was to add rather more than a quarter of a million to the increase in import values doting the cur- rent year. The actual clearances amounted to L.E. 1,786,070 against L.E. 1,509,936 for July 1905, the difference being one of L.E 276,134.

div.head: Metals.
div.p: Compared with the same period last year, the metal figures showed a substantial increase of L.E. 1592,006, mainly due to the gain of L.E. 110,021 in iron and iron goods. In this particular sub-division Belgium was credited with L.E. 63,753, France L.E. 24,938, Germany L.E. 24,063, and Great Britain L.E. 66,721. The shipments of agricultural machinery at L.E. 19,605 were L.E. 11,261 higher than in 1905, Switzerland sending L.E. 3,832 and America L.E. 1,146. Belgium supplied the whole of the railway and tramway rolling stock valued at L.E. 14,292, and Germany the locomotives (L.E. 1,278). The general machinery classification—from which are excluded all agricultural machines and locomotives—totaled L.E. 87,894, being so expansion of LE 36,339. Italy's share was LE 17,017 whilst those of France and Germany were LE 15,414 and LE 11,387 respectively.

div.head: Cereals.
div.p: The returns for this category amounted to LE 221,823, being an increase of LE 66,913 over 1905. The floor clearances were 12,283,141 kilograms, against 6,742,378 twelve months ago, and the difference in value LE 41,602. France, of course, supplied the greater part of the shipments, her figures of LE 62,477 being followed by Russia with LE 14,933.

div.head: Colonial Produce.
div.p: The increase here was one of LE 24,202, the principal contributor being sugar with a gain of LE 13,367. Germany's footing in this trade—of which special mention was made in a recent Journal—shows no sign of diminishing, her clearances during June and July having totalled LE 41,827.

div.head: Textiles.
div.p: The total imports under this heading were valued at LE. 404,761—a gain of LE 13,991 over the previous July. Manchester goods were up LE 9 162, thus reducing the drop on the year to LE 99,919. The clearances in bags at LE 15,287 were LE 8,602 greater than in 1905, but on the other hand, carpets were LE 4,227 down. Silk fabrics advanced LE 5 049, though the gross returns for 1906 are still LE 10,995 to the bad.

div.head: China and Glassware.
div.p: Belgium led to way with LE 6,758, being followed by Austria (LE 4,808) and Germany LE 4,504). The increase in the classification was LE 8,533.

div.head: Timber and Coal.
div.p: The only category of any moment showing a decrease on the month was the timber and coal division—in which furniture is included— where the net loss amounted to LE 51,103.

div.head: Timber.
div.p: Timber to the vaine of LE 115,308 passed through the Customs, against L.E. 162,763 in 1905, the shrinkage thus being LE 47,455. Turkey contributed LE 45,408. Sweden LE 32,531 and England LE 16,956.

div.head: Coal.
div.p: The coal returns of 52,257 tons valued at LE 35,197 show a decrease of 13,028 tons and LE 12,255.

div.head: Furniture.
div.p: The shipments of furniture from France and England were in each case slightly over LE 7,000, Austria following with LE 6,035 and Germany with LE 5,704. The increase on the month was LE 10,174, which thus brings the total clearances for the year in this sub- division up tp LE 228,191.

div.head: England's share.
div.p: Although, as we have already mentioned, the expansion in Egypt's import trade during July amounted to LE 276,134, we find that Great Britain only shares in the same to the extent of LE 33,084, our normal of 33.1% thus dropping to 11.9% A glance at home country's figures readily affords an explanation of the above low percentage, for it will be seen that her returns suffered to the extent of LE 9 308 under the combined clearances of coal and Manchester goods. With these two yielding a loss, the chances of an expansion in England's figures for any particular month can never be very great, and in the present instance had it not been for the support of the metal category, our proportion of the country's additional trade during July would have been a very small one. The iron trade yielded a net gain of L.E. 32,551 in England's favor whilst the general metal goods (excluding those of copper, brass, bronze and iron) contributed an increase of L.E. 8,370. Agricultural machinery shipments from Great Britain were heavier by L.E. 6,443. With the above exceptions, the movements on the credit side of England , ledger were practically unimportant, the largest figures being, with one exception, within LE, 3 500 of the returns for 1905. Apart from coal, with a loss of LE 11,581 there were no very serions declines in Great Britain's shipments. Locomotives dropped LE 6,124, rolling stock LE 5,655 and the unclassified cereals LE 6,899.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain necessary limits - free discussion

div.head: THE REV. PETER RUDOLPH.
div.p: To The Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir,- My name has of late come so prominently before the Egyptian public in reference to the Purification of Alexandria that the following additional facts as to my life and work here will undoubtedly be of interest to the public :— My work here has been so successful that I have become part and parole of all nationalities In fact people of all nations, both rich and poor, come and ask for advice, which I most willingly give, regardless of time, cost or trouble. Owing to my work making or oblig-ing me to mix with a very large number of people of different classes of Society, I can meet the demands of one by obliging the necessities of the other. During my visits as well at through the many applicants who came to me to many of whom were blind, who seemed to live in such a miserable existence, continually walking about in the dark by the assistance of others, who always seemed to me to look upon it is a great trial to themselves, (but what most have been the trial of the blind, without the knowledge of our Heavenly Father's light, miserable, ah ! miserable indeed ! ) I thought of trying to make their life brighter, not only by teaching the blind to read, but by learning them a craft, such as making baskets, chairs, etc. What was necessary was. Asylum and an asylam meant money any way meant work, and I did the work, and the work got the other. I first went to the late lamented Geo. Goussiou, who was an intimate friend of mine and told him what I had in my heart and the fellow feeling I had for the poor suffering blind humanity. I told him starving for food was bad enough, but how much worse most it be to not only be starving bat to be blind as wall which kept yon from relieving your want He saw the need of an Asylum and be said "It needs work and plenty of it, Mr. Rudolph." I volunteered to do the work and we carried it through. We got a Home at Moharrem Bey which need to be Mr. Archer's house. Through my efforts and Mr. Goussiou's, money simply flew in. The first bedstead I obtained from a Jewish lady named Mrs. Levick. Mr. Goussiou unfortunately obtained a Director for the Home whom I did not think suitable. I com- plained to Goussiou, but he said the man was all right, money was coming in, and I had only to have patience. Patience I had bat I could not stand that Director, so I resigned and in a very abort time the Home was closed. A year or two after Lord and Lady Meath came here and amongst one of their enquiries was "Have you a Home for the Blind here " When answered in the negative the was recommended to come and see me. Her ladyship did. 1 told her of my former experience with regard to the first Blind Asylum I had founded and the cause or its closing. She was pleased with the work I had done, but said "with your assistance, Mr. Rudolph, we'll get a second. I introduced her consequently to some of the wealthiest people in Alexandria, amongst whom was Baron Jack de Menasoe. Amongst such wealthy supporters her Ladyship turned her back on me, (although I care little for that, I help the poor in God's name, not mine). The Home for the blind was founded a second time and her ladyship got the profit of doing it
Truly Yours, Peter Rudolph.
September 9th, 1906.
The Rudolph Home,
Alexandria

div.head: PURIFICATION OF ALEXANDRIA.
(To the Editor of "The Egyptian Gazette.")
div.p: Sir,—Under the above and similar heading, many articles and letters have appeared in the press, but perhaps the letter most worthy of note is that from the pen of Mr. Knight Foley, who grasps the situation in a sensible manner, inasmuch as the persons who are waging this most unwarrantable war against our "sinning sisters" are probably equally sinful Far better to look for morality at home ; and leave the "sinning sisters" to their Maker, instead of driving them from pillar to post, and to perhaps a worse life, than they are at present leading. Yousbashi Blatt- ner and the Morality Brigade will never stamp it out; far better leave it alone altogether than take up a line of persecution that cannot help but end in absolute failure and discredit to those who are polling the wires. If the Rev. Peter Rudolph has been so many years trying to stamp this evil out, and has not succeeded, sorely it is not much use anyone taking it up where he left off. Apparently his teachings are not live and let live.
Thanking you in advance, I enclose my card and remain, Yours faithfully.
JUSTICE
Alexandria, September 10th

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Mohamed Aly Pasha yesterday visited Fakhry Pasha, Minister of Public Works, at Sun Stefano Hotel. The Prince afterwards left for Cairo.
Prince Ibrahim Pasha Hilmi, uncle of the Khedive, who is now stopping at Shepbeard's Hotel will leave for Europe on Saturday next. His Highness recently sold his palace at El-Munelreh for LE 100,000.
The Khedivah Mother will in allprobability spend the coming winter season in Constantinople.

The report published in the British Press that Lord Kitchener will shortly be appointed to the Irish command is discredited in India, as it is thought that for too much remains to be done in India to justify the removal of the Commander in Chief, whose task is regarded as only half complete.
It will be remembered that we stated a few days ago that no importance was attached to the report in military quarters in England.
Luzzato Pasha, general manager of the Bank of Egypt, arrived yesterday at Alexandria on his return from Europe.
Tito Hékékyan Pasha and wife, of Alexandria, have arrived at Wiesbadeu from Paris, and have taken apartments at the Hotel Nassau.

It is stated that Sheikh Mohamed Shaker, President of the Ulema Board of Alexandria, will be appointed Vice Chancellor of Al-Azhar University after the return of the Khedive. He will also retain his present position.

div.head: TINNED MEATS IN EGYPT.
div.p: A correspondent writes:-

The "Egyptian Gazette" has rendered a public service by exposing, the absurdly weak reply of Mr. Armour to the "Jungle" exposures and whatever the Egyptian agents of the Chicago packing firm may say, they will find it a hard task to restore public confidence is Mr. Amour's products. I will conclude with the following extract from a remarkable article in last month's "Westminster Review," quoted is the "Review of Reviews" :— To make even an approximate approach to the elimination of diseased meat it would be necessary to inspect every animal before being slaughtered and put into quarantine every one that was noticeably unhealthy, and either to keep it under observation until quite well or to kill it and destroy the carcase. It would then be necessary to inspect every animal as it is killed in order to prevent the fraudulent removal of the internal organs. It would then be necessary to examine these organs in detail and to destroy (so for as human food is con- cerned) the bodies of animals whose organs were found unhealthy. And then, when you have done all this and have destroyed thousands of dead bodies which would otherwise have been eaten, you will have no assurance that the animal was not suffering from an early form of one of the most loathsome and mali- gnant diseases the whole time. The writer illustrates his point by referring to the great difficulty that confronts the best medical skill in deciding whether a growth in the richest patient it cancerous or not. How much greater the difficulty in regard to the possible diseases of cattle !

In retaliation for the murder of police and soldiers by the terrorists, the troops sa Siedlce (Poland) began a general massacre of civilians on Saturday evening which was continued yesterday. Hundreds of people bave been killed or wounded. (Retuter)
The scenes of massacre and pillage at Siedlce lasted for 86 hours. Over 60 persons were killed and 200 wounded.

(Later). The massacre at Siedlce was appalling; 100 persons have been killed and 800 wounded : the Jewish quarter has been looted and resisters were shot down : the Christians avoided having their houses looted by hanging crosses outside : 1,000 persons, chiefly Jewish, bars been arrested and mercilessly beaten. (Reuter)
The terrorists have attacked the troops, who in turn have burned down the Ghetto and killed a hundred persons ; the wounded number 200. (Havas)

Mr. Urquhart, the British Vice-Consul here, was attacked by two assailants in the centre of the town. They fired at him and inflicted six wounds, none of which were serious. Mr. Urquhart, who is the manager of big works here, is unpopular owing to his attitude towards the strike. The Government has expressed its regret to the British Embassy, and promised the immediate punishment of the perpetrators of the outrage. (Reuter)

div.head: MOROCCO IN REVOLT. INSURGENTS SEIZE MOGADOR.

div.p: The insurgents are in possession of Mogador. The Government troops have sided with them. (Reuter)
The disorders continue at Mogador. Kaid Anflous has rebelled. He is molesting the Jews and Europeans. (Havas)

div.head: CRISIS IN PERSIA. TRIBUTES TO BRITISH PRESTIGE.

div.p: The "Times" considers the use of the British Legation at Teheran as an asylum as an event of unusual significance, and a remarkable tribute to British prestige amongst Persians, which, it says, would be shaken if the protection was withdrawn. (Feuter)

The Emperor has suddenly decided not to attend the manceuveres in Dalmatia. A slight indisposition is alleged to be the reason, but it is believed to be due to the fear of provoking disorders between the various races of Dalmatia. (Feuter)
It is officially announced that the Emperor has gone to Ischl for a fortnight owing to his suffering from a slight chill. (Feuter)

div.head: SOUTH AFRICAN RAILWAYS. END OF RATE WAR.

div.p: The threatened railway rates war between Cape Colony and Natal has been averted owing to the intervention of Lord Elgin, whose decision is received with satisfaction through of the country. (Reuter)
The Khedive has been recieved in audience by the Emperor Franz Josef at Schoenbrunn. (Feuter)
The "Daily Telegraph" learns from Tokio that Viscount Hayashi has expressed his intention of resigning from the Foreign Secretaryship. (Reuter)

div.head: ENGLAND AND GERMANY. IMPORTANT STATEMENT BY PRINCE BULOW.
div.p: Mr. Sidney Whitman, who was recently a guest of Prince Bulow, the German Imperial Chancellor, during the latter's stay at Nor- derney, contributes to the "Daily Mail" an interesting statement by the Prince as to the Relations between Germany:— "I admit," said the Prince, "that we have made great strides in shipbuilding; for, like other nations, we require a fleet in proportion to the extent of our commercial internets all over the water. But as a matter of fact, our Navy is still very small in proportion to our overseas commerce – judging their relative dimensions by those of other nations. To argue, however, that Germany thinks of ever competing with England for the mastery of the sea is tantamount to accusing us of wishing to build a railway to the moon, including rolling-stock, sleeping cars, and c. It is sheer nonsense, and I for one deplore that anybody should deem me capable of entertaining such a fantastic idea." "And yet, fantastic though it be," I ventured to rejoin, there are people in England who further believe that Germany is endeavoring to checkmate England wherever she can, either in Turkey or China, and, within the last few days, even in the Persian Gulf." "Yes," Prince Billow replied, "I am aware of that But what fondation is there for assuming anything beyond that commercial rivalry which is as legitimate as it is universal all the world over I Remember that two years ago a section of the English Press affected to see the hand of Germany behind the recalcitrance of Tibet. What nonsense! "Then, again, the Press agitation in connection with the Bagdad Railway. This project never was and never could be more than a purely commercial undertaking as far as Germany is concerned. We are all commercial rivals in Turkey, and nothing more. All of us are intent on making money in Turkey ; but whereat some try to do so without waiting to give a fair equivalent in return, those Germans who are successful there, at least work for their hire. They work hard and conscientiously, they produce something—see the Anatolian Railway—the German hospitals and schools in Turkey—"hey give a fair return for what they get." With regard to the recent meeting between the German Emperor and the King of England, Prince Billow said: "A deal of what has been written on the subject is doubtless due to its being the hot summer season; the editors of the newspapers are away on their holidays, and those who take their place are naturally anxious to show their zeal. Acute political questions were not disposed at Cronberg, for the simple reason that such do not exist, as between England and Germany. The meeting of the two monarchs marks an auspicions stage on the road to the gradual elimination of misunderstanding between the two countries. The cordial reception given to the King of England was in full accordance with the esteem felt for the sovereign of a great country, as also with the admiration inspired by his statesmanlike qualities."

div.head: A POSTAL MEZZOFANTI.
div.p: The Dutch papers print a curious story about telegraph messenger, living at Breda. The man is about fifty years of age now, and has been able, by self study only, to master an unusual number of languages, being able to speak and write in the following tongues – English, French, German, Danish, Spanish, Italian, Arabic, Latin, Greek, Hebrew, and Sanscrit, besides being able to decipher hieroglyphic and cuneiform inscriptions. Further, he possesses no mean acquaintance with cosmography, astronomy, physios, the history of art, and various other sciences. The report say that this simple man, who spends his long working day by carrying telegrams to their destination, is often consulted by other linguists on varions subtle questions. He is also alleged to possets the rare gifs of writing Greek poems. There is now a movement to find this extraordinary man a career better suited to his capacities than that of postal messenger, and it is meeting with general support.

div.head: HOTEL TELEPHONES.
div.p: One hotel in New York city does more phone business, according to a New York paper, than is transected by the exchanges of many towns. The 1,117,648 persons at the new Hotel Astor last year, and the 220,196 guests who slept there during the same period of time, are of a class who make much use of the telephone; yet the extent of their patronage is something of a surprise to those who see the figures for the first time. There was a total of 25,000 city calls registered at the hotel for the month of April, 1906, and for the same month 2,500 suburban and long: distance calls appear upon the record. Supposing the other months to show similar totals, the aggregate number of calls of all kinds, exclusive of those coming in for the year, would be 330,000. The total revenue from telephone use is something like 10,000 annually.

div.head: KAFFIR BRUTALITY.
THE AWFUL TORTURES OF MR. VEAL.
div.p: Captain R Tully, of South Shields, has, states the "Yorkshire Post," received a latter from his brother, Mr. Henry Tully, who has been nearly thirty years in South Africa. Writing from Pietermaritzburg, on July 28, Mr. Tully says :— 'I was very sorry to see that Keir Hardie and several other M.P.s who are in ignorance of the facts have accused the Natal troops of barbarity in connection with this war. They belong to the same sort of people who found bait with the British troops daring the Boer War. As far as the charge of barbarity is con- cerned, the very opposite was the case. The women and children were well taken care of and only the natives who were found in arms against us were killed. "The reason so few prisoners were taken was the atrocities committed on our men by the rebels. Brooks and Brown, of my old corps, the Natal Mounted Police, were most horribly mutilated. In the case of Veal a non-combatant, be must have suffered awful torture. A native witness has confessed to us that the poor fellow was held down while the soles of his feet were cut off. Hi fainted, and when he came to he was made to walk a distance, carrying a heavy load on his head. His right hand was ont off, and he had to salute himself with his dead hand. After that h's eyes were gonged out, and he was dismembered while still living. Can you wonder that the men of McKenzie's colomn, when they found hit mutilated body, should cry out, "Take no surrender, sir's Can you imagine anything more horrible than these outrages, or any people in their sane senses taking the part of the Black against their own country people t The Kaffirs who committed these cruelties are mission auction Kaffirs, mind you I "I have these deuils from Colonel Wells and others who were on the field and found the bodies. I only wish all the Anglophobes in the House of Commons would come out here and live among the natives for a short period. They would toon be convinced of their folly."

div.head: WHERE MARRIAGE IS REALLY A LOTTERY.
div.p: Sir J. George Scott, in an article in "Blackwood" on the marriage customs of some parts of India, writes that every years in the Ramai country, about October, a married lottery— a sort of sweethearts' sweep — is held. The names of all the marriageable girls and of the young men of the circle who want to get married are written on slips of paper and thrown into separate earthen pots. From these they are drawn against one another by the local wise man. This simply determines the fact that the Rumsi girl but come out and is ready to be married ; and the youth whose name is drawn against here thereby obtains a particular letter of introduction, with author- ity to make love immediately with what ardour and success he is capable of.

div.head: 3000 MILES RIDE FOR £2000 WAGER.
div.p: Three men, including an English ex-cavalryan, have spurted from Spokane on 8000 mile ride to New York, right across the United States, almost from the Pacific coast to the Atlantic A millionaire ranch and mine owner of Montana named King has offered them £2000 if they can cover the 8000 miles in ninety days. The Englishman is William Tucker, who served for some years in the English cavalry, and afterwards went with Strathcona's House to South Africa. The ride originated in a joke. Reardon, one of the riders, saw Mr. King, who said that he wanted to send a letter to Mr. McClellen, the Mayor of New York. Not hearing the destination of the letter, Reardon offered to take it, and King said laugh- ingly that it would take him more than ninety days. Reardon said that he would do it in less so the match was made.

div.head: A CO-OPERATIVE DINNER.
div.p: Three married couples in Birmingham have I succeeded in carrying out satisfactorily for a month a cooperative dinner. At the commencement to minimize the risk of disappoint- ment, each couple wrote down a list of dinners which they did not like, and it was resolved that the precise nature of the bill of I fare should be kept a secret. One of the greatest advantages of the scheme from the wives' point of view is that it allows each of them two mornings in the week on which they are absolutely free from any of the demmands which the cooking of the midday meal upon the time and temper of the ordinary woman.

div.head: THE PALESTINIAN CLUB.
div.p: This is the title of the newest organization of London Zionists Its programme extends from the publication of Zionist journals to the formation of an "export and import company" the interests of Palestinian trade, as well as of a company for the purchase, and sale of land. Other objects are the starting of industrial undertakings, the cultivation of Jewish art, and the formation of an international association of Jewish teachers. Generally, the aims of the movement are directed to the policy of gradual penetration into Palestine, and to this extent it is in harmony with the present objects of Zionism. Mr. Heinrich Rosenbaum, a member of the Actions Committee and the Council of the Jewish Colonial Trust, is at the head of the new organization.

div.head: THE PRODUCTION OF PAPER.
CONSUMPTION OF FORESTS.
div.p: Prof. R K. Duncan, of Kansas University, in the course of a series of articles contributed ' Harper's Magazine" on "The Wonders of Cellulose," deals in the September number with the production of paper. He says that if one asked "the man in the street" what paper was made of, be would almost certainly say "rage" but the answer would be absurdly inadequate, for there exists not one thousandth part of the rags that would be necessary. Oar civilization exists largely on paper buis, and in England alone it requires 650 mills, producing 30,000 tons a week to fulfil our needs. To feed these, science laid her hand on cellulose which we cannot make, but can only take tram plants. In the plant the cellulose of the cell walls, with the exception of cotton, which is unique, does not stand up pure and free, and uncombined, but exists always encrusted chemically with some other substance. The substance of woody fibre is thus always cellulose X, and the problem of science was either to manufacture paper directly out of cellulose X (lingo cellulose or wood fibre) or te devise some practical method of extracting the X substance from the cellulose, and thus obtain it pore and free for paper. Both methods are practiced today. Paper boxes, wrapping-paper and almost all the newspapers of the land, are made, not of rags, but simply of disintegrated deal boards pounded and mashed and amalgamated into paper. Any one of the Urge London or American daily papers consumers each day folly tan acres of an average forest. Such paper does not last. The wood fibre oat of which it is made is, unlike pore cellulose, acted upon by light and air and water and the organisms of decay. This is bad, bat not wholly bad, for most of the literature appearing on this paper is made as mechanically as the paper itself, and it is fitting that it should be as ephemeral in foot as it is in nature. England, alone, every year, imports some 350,000 tons of this mechanical wood pulp to turn it into paper. She imports also some 200,000 tons of what is called "chemical wood-pulp"—i.e., wood from which the en- crusting Impurities have been chemically removed, and which consists of cellulose almost pure. For chemistry has succeeded in doing this, and it is doubtful whether any chemical discovery of modem times has had a success so spontaneous and so immense in industrial value.

div.head: PRESIDENT AND PRINTER.
div.p: President Roosevelt is proceeding with characteristic vigor in his campaign against the English language. He has replied to the chorus of European condemnation by extending his order for ' simplified" spelling to all departments of the Federal Government. The disapproval, however, of his hasty and ill-conceived notion is by no means confined to one hemisphere. A large section of the American Press, Republican and Democratic alike, dedans that the President has injured his public reputation by an act of personal whim, and that him Whole policy may come under suspicion of being equally ill-considered and willful. It is urged with apparent reason that by inning his order he has trenched illegally upon the powers of the Executive, and has acted ultra vires. Bat the main feeling—in those quarters at least where Americanism is not rampant— is dismay at the blow struck against the homogeneity of the two branches of the Anglo Saxon race Not only will the masterpieces of our tongue be reproduced in a form which is unintelligible on this side of the Atlantic, bat a thick wedge will be driven between the growing literatures of the two countries; the demand for American-printed books will cease in England, and vice versa, and the heart bleeds for the unhappy foreigner who is required to master American as well as English.

div.head: HANOVER'S DOWNFALL.
div.p: Hanover made on Sunday what was probably its last ineffective protest against the fate which handed the country over to be absorbed in Prussia That day was the fortieth anniversary of the battle of Langensalza, when the Hanoverian army, utterly outnumbered, was compelled to capitulate. The occasion was converted into a great national demonstration, which was held upon the battlefeild itself, and was attended by many thousands of persons, most of them possessing a representative character. It had been intended to fly once more the old flag of Hanover on the feild of her ruin but the Prussian Government promptly intimidated that this would be seized as a seditious emblem. Orders had also been given to prohibit the demonstrationsif it threatened to assume as aspect too markedly anti-Prussian.

div.head: SHOCKED ECCLESIASTICS.
div.p: A grave scandal has been caused in Lutheran Church circles by the cremation of the body of a pastor named Schulz, at Maine Pastor Schulz was a well-known clergyman in Lorraine and a lecturer on theology at Metz In his will be left explicit instructions that his remains were to be cremated, and, as cremation is not permitted in Lorraine, that his body should be conveyed to the nearest crematorium Maine In Mets the clergy showed their disapproval of the cremation by accompanying the body of their late colleagues only to the railway station, and by declining to wear their usual ecclesiastical ornaments. On arrival at Mains, Herr Schuls's friends could find no clergyman to attend the cremation. In Prussia cremation is not permitted, clergy of both denominations opposing in introduction u a serions blow levelled at the popular belief in the resurrection of the body. In almost all other German States it is permitted.

div.head: ROMAN CATHOLICISM IN SPAIN.
div.p: It is very satisfactory to team that King Alfoso XIII. has signed the decree drawn up by his Ministers reestablishing Civil Marriage in Spain, and doing away with the vexations declarations u to the religion of the contracting parties in a marriage. It was thought that the influence of the Church of Rome, which is so powerful in Madrid, would have forced the young King to sacrifice the Lopes Dominguez Ministry sooner than embark on anti-clerical reforms. But Alfonso XIII. has studied England and France to some purpose, and be sees what his country needs if it is ever to fulfil his ambition, and once more take its place among the Great Powers. The re-establishment of Civil Marriage is not perhaps a very great reform in itself, but it is an appreciable step towards modernizing Spain.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
